Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying the Interactions Between the Financial Sector and the Macroeconomy in China: A Structural Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs will carry out data collection work that will shed new light on the Chinese economy as a whole. They will use publicly available detailed information on regular and off-balance-sheet intermediation activities by Chinese banks. From this information, they plan to create a longitudinal data set of economic aggregate measures that can be used to study the Chinese macroeconomy. Understanding China's financial markets and macroeconomy is crucial for the design of U.S. monetary and fiscal policy, with the overall goal of enhancing the competitiveness of the US economy in the global marketplace.

The PIs will make their data set publicly available. Their analysis will also employ structural models to study interactions between bank lending activities, macroeconomic policy, and the aggregate economy. Because China's economy has a number of structural differences from advanced economies, the PIs will adapt models used to study the U.S. and Europe to build these structural models. The PIs will also compare the various results of the structural models and use parameters from these models to estimate transitional dynamics in the economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data
We finished constructing two micro datasets at the level of individual banks and one macro time series data. The first dataset, named entrusted loan dataset, covers new entrusted loan between nonfinancial firms during 2009­2015. The second dataset, named bank asset dataset, covers two major categories on the asset side of individual banks’ balance sheet, bank loan and ARI excluding central bill. These two datasets will be released to the public in coming months. The third dataset consists of quarterly and monthly macro time series that allow researchers to study quantitative macroeconomics. 
We also collected loan-­level mortgage data, which can be used to analyze sources of the mortgage credit boom and the impact of credit policy changes on the mortgage market and consumers' behavior. This dataset is proprietary as it belongs to one of the four largest commercial banks in China. We have cleaned up the data usable for research.
The following public websites for free downloads of our data:   1. https://www.frbatlanta.org/cqer/research/china-macroeconomy.aspx (English version)   2. http://cmf.cafr.cn/data/listpage (Chinese version)   3. http://www.tzha.net/code (personal website)


Models
To understand China's institutional elements within a clear conceptual framework, we developed one theory for banks' optimal portfolio problem specific to the Chinese economy and another theory of optimal monetary policy of China.
In addition to this project, we completed two new research projects. One is assessment of the effects of the 2009 monetary stimulus on credit allocations and the macroeconomy. The other is to provide a theoretical framework to understand the existing quantity­-based monetary policy that has an endogenous switching rule as well as the transitional path toward an adoption of interest­-rate monetary policy.
We have successfully provided empirical evidence on (1) the interactions of China's monetary policy with banking regulations, (2) the effectiveness of monetary policy on the banking system with a rapidly growing sector of shadow banking in China, and (3) tradeoffs between short-­term gains in growth and long-­term vulnerability in financial markets.
The PIs show how monetary policy in China influences banks' shadow banking activities. We developed and estimated the endogenously switching monetary policy rule that is based on institutional facts and at the same time tractable. This development, along with two newly constructed micro banking datasets, enables us to establish the following empirical evidence. Contractionary monetary policy during 2009­2015 caused shadow banking loans to rise rapidly, offsetting the expected decline of traditional bank loans and hampering the effectiveness of monetary policy on total bank credit. We advance a theoretical explanation of our empirical findings.


Publications/outcomes
(1) ``The Nexus of Monetary Policy and Shadow Banking in China,'' American Economic Review, 2018, volume 108(12), pages 3891-3936. 
(2) ``Impacts of Monetary Stimulus on Credit Allocation and the Macroeconomy: Evidence from China,'' Revise and Resubmit, Econometrica. 
(3) ``The Great Housing Boom of China,'' American Economic Journal: Macroeconomics，2017, 9 (2), 73-114.
(4) ``Lending Efficiency Shock,'' Revise and Resubmit, Review of Economic Dynamics.
(5) ``Discount-Rate Shock, Price-Rent Variation, and the Business Cycle,'' Revise and Resubmit, International Economic Review.
(6) ``Macroeconomic Impacts of China's Financial Policies,'' Chapter 7, Handbook of China's Financial System, edited by Marlene Amstad, Guofeng Shen, and Wei Xiong, Princeton University Press, Forthcoming.
